body:
I've performed a quick test of the medium case
```bash
#Medium
python lstm_ptb.py --num-hidden 650  --lr-decay 0.8 --gpus 0
```
(The scale of the initializer is not the same as TF, need to fix it later)

The network can get a better ppl than the small version.
For the large case, I've manually changed the initialization scale to be mx.init.Uniform(0.04) and it gets better result
```bash
python lstm_ptb.py --num-hidden 1500  --lr-decay 0.87 --dropout 0.35 --max-norm 10 --gpus 0
```

@sxjscience Sorry, I used a wrong `lr_decay` setting. Reset it and the result is right. 
Additionally, the `num_embed` should also be set to same as `num_hidden`. But it will have little bearing on the result. 
Updated previous response:

```2017-04-19 16:38:25,920 Epoch:[9], Batch: [200]/[1327], lr: 0.640000, nll: 4.33644, ppl: 76.4347, grad_norm: 10.8647, ms/batch: 28.82
@tangjiasheng Thanks a lot! I will revise the script
Oh, I see.

@sxjscience these lines of code may be convenient for you, including several parameters not(maybe never haha) used. Just leaving the default setting to small config.
```
def load_medium_config(args):
    args.num_layers=2
    args.num_hidden=650
    args.num_embed=650
    args.lr_decay=0.8
    args.lr=1.0
    args.max_norm=5
    args.dropout=0.5
    args.batch_size=20
    args.bptt=35
    args.init_scale=0.05

def load_large_config(args):
    args.num_layers=2
    args.num_hidden=1500
    args.num_embed=1500
    args.lr_decay=1/1.15
    args.lr=1.0
    args.max_norm=10
    args.dropout=0.65
    args.batch_size=20
    args.bptt=35
    args.init_scale=0.04

mxnet now (since a week ago)  has a lot of additional sampling operators, see sample_op.h/cc and multisample-op.h/cc
The latter version is one where parameters for the distributions are input tensors.
So far we implemented exponential/gamma/poisson/negative binomial. And just for CPUs.
Will look whether we can add CPU-support for multinomial easily. Getting them all on GPUs as well is also something we will look at.

Examples also need unit tests.

https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/examples/image_retraining/retrain_test.py

https://github.com/tensorflow/models/blob/master/slim/nets/inception_resnet_v2_test.py

make sure your python-opencv and c++-opencv the same version.  you may check like this:
``` shell 
ldd mxent.so | grep opencv 
pip list | grep opencv 
````

Is this still an active issue? Am interested as I just implemented a bunch of new operators to MxNet and also am interested in running binarized networks.
Has anyone made any progress here? 
In terms of implementation, it seems for me that we would have to make some similar technique as C++ does for vector<bool>. Basically have a tensor<bool> that stores all entries packed in individual bits but allows access to individual bits by standard indexing. Implementing Boolean operators on such tensors would be trivial, the effort is in the additional tensor specialization.
Each gPU has its mean and variance,  and gamma and beta will be shared among all gpus.
Did you use clip_gradient? @magic282

You can use gdb for c++ and pdb for python.

This could be the reason of performance diff reported in the issues.  The new way to handle weight decay will cause un-convergence in my experiments.  Similar conclusion can be find in https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/243881/weight-decay-and-rmsprop-in-neural-networks

@alanhuang1990 Are you using the non-centered version or the centered version? The default now is RMSProp without momentum(noncentered) while it's previously RMSProp + Momentumn. 
Also, the correct way of handling weight decay is correct and if it makes the convergence worse, you may try to tune the learning-rate again.
I think the only thing need to be added is the channel-wise/depth-wise convolution

Discussion is needed due to this pr may involve some api change. The pr is raised to address dtype problem of kvstore, and it requires user to provide a `dtype` field in his DataIter: 
- https://github.com/ZihengJiang/mxnet/blob/kvstore/python/mxnet/model.py#L781
- https://github.com/ZihengJiang/mxnet/blob/kvstore/python/mxnet/model.py#L503

But looks like there exists some legacy case which uses tuple as `provide_data`? https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tests/python/train/test_dtype.py#L130

@piiswrong @mli

model and module need to parse provide_data and convert to datadesc if necessary.
see example in module and executor_group

@eric-haibin-lin I found a way to consistently reproduce the issue on my machine.
1. Run `./a.out` (lenet example)
2. Wait until training begins.
3. Run `stress -i 1000` (this stress tool is available in most distributions)
4. lenet example crashs and print `free(): invalid pointer`. Sometimes it do not immediately crash, just wait a few seconds then kill `stress`, `lenet` will crash after `stress` being killed.

I really appreciate your help in this issue. Thank you.

this commit:

in this file:
mxnet\src\operator\tensor\broadcast_reduce_op_index.cc

there are many "LSLSLS" at the ends of lines when viewed on windows

`MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS` specifies how many jobs can be run in parallel, while `OMP_NUM_THREADS` roughly means how many threads will be used in a single job.

For MKLML, @zhenlinluo knows better than me.
@piiswrong shall we recommend to use `mx.rnn` instead of `mx.sym.RNN`?

@sxjscience Fix a minor bug for your code when run it on multi gpus, the evaluation and testing phase should be allocated to single gpu.
```
File "lstm_ptb.py", line 165, in evaluate
    axis=-1).asnumpy()
mxnet.base.MXNetError: Shape inconsistent, Provided=(20,10), inferred shape=(20,5)
```
I fixed the code in a lazy(not clean) way. Since the lines are so little, no need to send a PR, you can just modify it with your PR:
```
    # add this for eval and test phase.
    test_contexts = [contexts[0]]
    test_net = mx.mod.Module(mx.sym.Group([logits_sym] +
                                          [mx.sym.BlockGrad(ele) for ele in next_states]),
                             data_names=["data"],
                             label_names=None,
                             state_names=[state.name for state in prev_state_list],
                             context=test_contexts)
```
New to MXNet, maybe we can perform a distributed evaluation? Not sure.

I used `train_cifar10.py` and met the same problem. My code is below: 
```Python
import os
import argparse
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)
from common import find_mxnet, data, fit
from common.util import download_file
import mxnet as mx

def download_cifar10():
    #data_dir="data"
    #fnames = (os.path.join(data_dir, "cifar10_train.rec"),
    #          os.path.join(data_dir, "cifar10_val.rec"))
    #download_file('http://data.mxnet.io/data/cifar10/cifar10_val.rec', fnames[1])
    #download_file('http://data.mxnet.io/data/cifar10/cifar10_train.rec', fnames[0])
    fnames = range(2)
    fnames[0] = '/home/yuens/Software/mxnet/mydata_val.rec'
    fnames[1] = '/home/yuens/Software/mxnet/mydata_train.rec'
    return fnames

if __name__ == '__main__':
    # download data
    (train_fname, val_fname) = download_cifar10()

    # parse args
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="train cifar10",
                                     formatter_class=argparse.ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter)
    fit.add_fit_args(parser)
    data.add_data_args(parser)
    data.add_data_aug_args(parser)
    data.set_data_aug_level(parser, 2)
    parser.set_defaults(
        # network
        network         = 'resnet',
        num_layers      = 110,
        # data
        data_train      = train_fname,
        data_val        = val_fname,
        num_classes     = 10,
        num_examples    = 50000,
        image_shape     = '3,55,55',#32
        pad_size        = 0,
        # train
        batch_size      = 1,#128,
        num_epochs      = 30,
        lr              = .05,
        lr_step_epochs  = '200,250',
    )
    args = parser.parse_args()

    # load network
    from importlib import import_module
    net = import_module('symbols.'+args.network)
    #net = import_module('symbols.'+)
    #import symbol_unet
    #net = symbol_unet.get_symbol()
    sym = net.get_symbol(**vars(args))

    # train
    #mx.sym.Variable(init=mx.init.Xavier)
    fit.fit(args, sym, data.get_rec_iter)
    prefix = "ssnet-dogcat-55"
    num_epochs = 25
    mx.model.save_checkpoint(prefix=prefix, epoch=num_epochs)
```

@sxjscience 
i imitate your implementation to support multi-gpu. And i use mx.nd operation as soon as possible. 
i am not sure whether it's right
The code is as followed:

```
    def norm_clipping(self, threshold=1.0):
        """Clip the norm according to the threshold.
        All the gradients are concatenated to a single vector and the overall norm is calculated.
        Follows `[ICML2013] On the difficulty of training recurrent neural networks`

        Parameters
        ----------
        threshold : float, optional

        Returns
        -------
        norm_val : float
            The norm value. It could be used to measure whether the gradients are stable.
        """
        assert self.binded and self.params_initialized
        norm_val = self.get_global_norm_val()
	for i in range(len(self._exec_group.execs)):
            if norm_val[i] > threshold:
           	ratio = threshold / float(norm_val[i])
            	for grads in self._exec_group.grad_arrays:
                    grads[i][:] *= ratio

    def get_global_norm_val(self):
        """Get the overall gradient norm ||W||_2

        Parameters
        ----------
        net : mx.mod.Module

        Returns
        -------
        norm_val : float
        """
        assert self.binded and self.params_initialized

	import numpy as np
        norm_val = np.zeros(len(self._exec_group.execs))
	for grad_arr in self._exec_group.grad_arrays:
	    for i in range(len(self._exec_group.execs)):
		l2_norm = nd.square(nd.norm(grad_arr[i] / self._exec_group.batch_size)).asscalar()
		norm_val[i] += l2_norm
        return np.sqrt(norm_val)
```

Thanks very much! I'll go back to Hong Kong tomorrow and will begin to finish this.

@sxjscience<https://github.com/sxjscience>
i imitate your implementation to support multi-gpu. And i use mx.nd operation as soon as possible.
i am not sure whether it's right
The code is as followed:

def norm_clipping(self, threshold=1.0): """Clip the norm according to the threshold. All the gradients are concatenated to a single vector and the overall norm is calculated. Follows[ICML2013] On the difficulty of training recurrent neural networks`

    Parameters
    ----------
    threshold : float, optional

    Returns
    -------
    norm_val : float
        The norm value. It could be used to measure whether the gradients are stable.
    """
    assert self.binded and self.params_initialized
    norm_val = self.get_global_norm_val()
for i in range(len(self._exec_group.execs)):
        if norm_val[i] > threshold:
        ratio = threshold / float(norm_val[i])
                for grads in self._exec_group.grad_arrays:
                grads[i][:] *= ratio

def get_global_norm_val(self):
    """Get the overall gradient norm ||W||_2

    Parameters
    ----------
    net : mx.mod.Module

    Returns
    -------
    norm_val : float
    """
    assert self.binded and self.params_initialized
    #TODO The code in the following will cause the estimated norm to be different for multiple gpus
import numpy as np
    norm_val = np.zeros(len(self._exec_group.execs))
for grad_arr in self._exec_group.grad_arrays:
    for i in range(len(self._exec_group.execs)):
        l2_norm = nd.square(nd.norm(grad_arr[i] / self._exec_group.batch_size)).asscalar()
        norm_val[i] += l2_norm
    return np.sqrt(norm_val)


`

Apologies, have been away at a conference for the past week, and haven't had time to follow up on the changes needed to DML-CORE. I will either do it today, or next week Tuesday. Unless someone else wants to do it first.

One other thing: this should be merged soon (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5834), which will simplify your code a bit as: 

- the new CTC loss operator returns the actual CTC loss. So there is no need to write your own much slower Python implementation in `stt_metric.py` 
- don't need instructions to the user on building WarpCTC 
- your implementation will work on Windows (your current implementation relies on WarpCTC, which doesn't have a Windows build script)
